title: Warli Painting
hero_image_alt: White tribal figures dancing on a brown background
short_description: A tribal art form from Maharashtra using simple white circles, triangles, and squares to depict daily life.
long_description:
Warli painting is a style of tribal art mostly created by the tribal people from the North Sahyadri Range in Maharashtra. The paintings are rudimentary and use a very basic graphic vocabulary: a circle, a triangle, and a square. 

Traditionally done on mud walls using rice paste (white) on a red ochre background, Warli art depicts social life rather than mythological characters. Scenes of hunting, dancing (Tarpa dance), sowing, and harvesting are common. The philosophy is one of harmony with nature.
traditional_methods: Preparing background with cow dung/red mud.
Painting with bamboo stick chewed at the end.
motifs_and_meanings: Tarpa Dance: Spiral formation representing the circle of life.

major_centres.title: Dahanu / Palghar
major_centres.summary: Tribal villages where the art originated.

authenticity_tips: Authentic Warli is monochromatic (White on Brown/Red).
